Now, to answer "how to test a private method" (which should also be in the
FAQ!), I saw three general solutions in our discussion of a few weeks ago:
 
1) Don't test it.  Said Kent Beck: "This will require you to rethink your
design. Every time I've taken the time to think about visibility because of
testing, I've found valuable insight into the design as a whole, and my need
to test private methods has disappeared, either because they become public
or because they move to another class where they are public."
 
2) There's a rumor that if you use Java reflection to access the method,
there's a way to tweak the Java security settings to allow the call.  Not
sure how exactly to do this though.
 
3) Add "testability API's" to your production classes and document heavily
the fact that they are not intended to be called by shipping code.  One way
to "document" this fact is to deprecate these methods, then always compile
your production code with deprecation checking on, and your test code with
it off.  Kind of hackish though.
 
Kevin
